Like many western river ecosystems, the Middle Rio Grande faces numerous challenges in balancing competing needs within a finite water supply and other resource constrains. Historical practices by our ancestors and immigrants to the Middle Rio Grande have established the conditions that we have inherited. Long-term drought exacerbated by climate change is changing conditions that affect natural and human communities as we strive to improve our precious Rio Grande.The Middle Rio Grande/Albuquerque Urban Waters Federal Partnership will reconnect our urban communities, particularly those that are overburdened or economically distressed, with the waterway by improving coordination among federal agencies and collaborating with community-led revitalization efforts. Our projects will improve our community water systems and promote their economic, environmental and social benefits. Specifically, the Middle Rio Grande/Albuquerque Urban Waters Federal Partnership will support the development of the Valle de Oro National Wildlife Refuge, the first urban refuge in the Southwest, as well as numerous restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande/Albuquerque, a pilot watershed-based storm water management program, a climate change project, and transportation and economic development initiatives in the South Valley.Users can discover more about the project on the partnerships website, http://www.urbanwaters.gov/mid-riogrande/index.html.The portion of the partnership data provided by the Bureau of Reclamation in support of the project is based in significant part on data compiled in support the mapping exercise for the DOI Secretary•À_•À_•À_?•À_•À_?•À_s 2012 Middle Rio Grande Conservation Initiative Report http://middleriogrande.com/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=zWjw3lgpeyE%3d&tabid=488&mid=1401&forcedownload=true> The data compiled for this report was ultimately presented in the Appendix as maps and tabular data and ultimately no metadata was produced other than at the attribute level. The original data•À_•À_•À_?•À_•À_?•À_s scope was identified as applicable in support of the Urban Waters Partnership since the partnership seeks to advance the work of the America•À_•À_•À_?•À_•À_?•À_s Great Outdoors Initiative http://www.doi.gov/americasgreatoutdoors/index.cfm>, of which the 2012 MRG Conservation Initiative was a part of. This data represents an updated and revised dataset of similar scope with additions identifying Conservation, Education, and Recreation opportunities within the Middle Rio Grande region from Cochiti Reservoir through Elephant Butte Reservoir and as such depicts features from a more broad geographic area of interest than the Urban Waters Partnership.Originally, maintenance and restoration work was included in the point feature class of the MRG Conservation Initiative and classified as a Conservation activity; however, many of the restoration activities are better represented by a polyline feature class. The dynamic nature of the expected deployment of this data allowed for the better representation of each activity as either a point or a polyline. Subsequently, the maintenance and restoration activities have been removed from the comparible layer in the Urban Waters dataset, UrbanWaters_POIs_Points and devided into two feature classes as appropriate, MRG_Activities_line and MRG_Activities_multipoint. Unlike the Urban Waters POIs feature classes in which features share overalap in representation between point and polygon coverages, these to maintenance and restoration activity feature classes are mutually exclusive.The MRG Conservation Initiative dataset was compiled by the Technical Services Division of the Albuquerque Area Office of the Bureau of Reclamation from multiple sources. Because of the congestive nature of the static maps published in the 2012 report, several lesser projects were ommitted in 2012. The dataset for the Urban Waters Program however, while not depicting any new activities from either 2013 or 2014, has been expanded to depict all identified activities from 2002 to 2012. Many maintenance and restoration activities coincide with previous activities also resident in this dataset, therfore portions of or wholly coincident geometries may identify multiple featues discernable only through interogating the data with the identify tool.The source geometry for this feature class is a derivative of the National Hydrographic Dataset (NHD) Flowline feature class. Along much of the Rio Grande, this feature class is classified as an artificial path, i.e., a geometric network path used for directed flow analysis. Often these artificial paths do not accurately represent the geometry of the river because they are covered by a polygon for cartographic purposes. In any case, the NHD is out of date, especially over dynamic features like rivers such as the Rio Grande which change annually and indeed with every precipitation or release event. Therefore, the source geometry will not reflect the ground truth alignment of the Rio Grand at larger scales. All locations are approximate and in no case does the geometry reflect or is intended to reflect the actual maintenance and restoration activities.

Title: New Mexico Environment Department (NMED) Districts
Description: This feature layer contains District Boundaries for the New Mexico Environment Department (NMED). The layer was created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 USGS Liason and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS Support using 2010 Census Bureau TIGER/Line county boundaries and the NMED supported EGIS Mapper feature layer at http://gis.nmenv.state.nm.us/EGIS/. The district boundaries are current as of 5/4/2012. / District Field Offices include the following. District I: Gallup, Grants, Rio Rancho, Albuquerque, Los Lunas, Socorro, Tucumcari, Clovis. District II: Farmington, Espanola, Santa Fe, Las Vegas, Raton, Taos. District III: Silver City, Deming, Las Cruces, Alamogordo, Ruidoso, Roswell, Carlsbad, Hobbs.

Title: New Mexico Homeland Security and Emergency Management Districts
Description: This dataset represents the boundaries for the New Mexico Homeland Security Emergency Management districts. The dataset was created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 per a map of the districts contained in the document "New Mexico Family Emergency Preparedness Guide" (page 5) http://www.nmdhsem.org/uploads/files/New%20Mexico%20Family%20Emergency%20Preparedness%20Guide%20High%20Quality.pdf and verified by Don Shainin of NM don.shainin@state.nm.us.

Title: 112th Congressional Districts in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: Boundaries of the US 112th Congressional Districts in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 states (AR, LA, NM, OK, TX). Original datalayer compiled by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS from individual state layers. Attributes and boundaries updated to match official boundaries. Clipped to Region 6 Census 2010 boundary.

Title: EPA/USCG Jurisdictional Boundary
Description: US Coast Guard/Environmental Protection Agency response jurisdiction boundary

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6/US Coast Guard Jurisdictional Boundary (Lines)
Description: Lines defining the US Coast Guard/Environmental Protection Agency response jurisdiction boundary along the Louisiana and Texas coasts.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6/US Coast Guard Jurisdictional Boundary (Polygon)
Description: Polygon defining the US Coast Guard/Environmental Protection Agency response jurisdiction boundary along the Louisiana and Texas coasts.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 3000 foot Grid Cells in Albuquerque, NM area
Description: Grid of 3000' cells in the Albuquerque, NM area. Further documentation unknown.

Title: Facility Response Plan (FRP) Sites in Region 6, 5/2011
Description: This dataset includes locations of sites noted as having a Facility Response Plan (FRP). Having an FRP demonstrates a facility's preparedness to respond to a worst case oil discharge. Under the Clean Water Act, as amended by the Oil Pollution Act, certain facilities that store and use oil are required to prepare and submit these plans. Dataset received from Weston Solutions in May 2011.

Title: National Priorities List Boundaries (NPL), 9/18/2012, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: Boundaries for most of the sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 which are documented as being part of the National Priorities List as of September 18, 2012. Boundaries could not be determined for all NPL sites, therefore the layer NPLpt09182012 should be referenced to obtain locations for all NPL sites.

Title: Superfund National Priorities List (NPL) Sites, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6,  05/24/2013, Public
Description: Point locations for sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 which are documented as being part of the National Priorities List as of May 24, 2013. The locations were determined by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Superfund RPMs.

Title: Oklahoma Emergency Management Contacts for U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 ER
Description: This dataset is a file geodatabase table containing Oklahoma Emergency Management Directors by county as of March 20, 2012. Some counties have multiple directors. This dataset was created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Emergency Response GIS from the document http://www.ok.gov/OEM/documents/012011localem.pdf available at http://www.ok.gov/OEM/Publications_&_Forms/Oklahoma_Emergency_Management_Contacts/index.html. The document is current as of March 20, 2012.

Title: Oklahoma Corporation Commission District Boundaries
Description: This dataset represents Oklahoma Corporation Commission Oil and Gas Division district boundaries. U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Emergency Response GIS used the online map http://www.occeweb.com/og/ogdistricts.htm and the Census Bureau's 2010 TIGER/Line County layer to delineate the district boundaries.

Title: Oklahoma Office of Homeland Security Hazmat Response Districts
Description: This dataset was created by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Emergency Response GIS USGS liaison using the online map "Oklahoma Regional Response System" found at http://www.ok.gov/homeland/documents/RRS%20Area%20Map%20(3.19.12).pdf and Census Bureau 2010 TIGER/Line county boundaries. It represents Oklahoma Office of Homeland Security and Oklahoma State Department of Health hazmat response district boundaries.

Title: Region 6 Parcel Boundary Collection
Description: County and parish boundary layer with attributes listing the availability of parcel layers in the R6 GIS. Use in combination with layers found in \\r6gis1\share1\Admin\Parcels\.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Brownfields KMZ, June 2012
Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Brownfields KMZ dataset includes properties involved in the Region 6 Brownfields program. The locations of many of the properties included in the dataset have been reviewed by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Superfund for accuracy. Brownfields are lands involved in expansion, redevelopment, or reuse having the presence or potential presence of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant. See http://www.epa.gov/brownfields/ for further information.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Brownfields
Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Brownfields shapefile dataset includes properties involved in the Region 6 Brownfields program. The layer was created from coordinates obtained from the ACRES database on 6/26/2012. Locations for most of the sites were reviewed by Brownfields staff for accuracy and corrected where possible. Region 6 Brownfields programs have reviewed most of the sites and made corrections where necessary. / [ Brownfields are lands involved in expansion, redevelopment, or reuse having the presence or potential presence of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant. See http://www.epa.gov/brownfields/ for further information.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Brownfields Dec. 2011
Description: Locations of Region 6 Brownfield projects per coordinates from the ACRES database as of 12/06/2011 in shapefile format.

Title: Race, Ethnicity, Housing Unit Calculations, 2010 Census, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 States
Description: The fields in this table are a combination of fields from the 2010 Public Law 94-171 table distributed by the US Census Bureau and calculations made by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS to support population "race/ethnicity/age" mapping by Census Block. Calculations were made by race for persons being of "one or more races", "one race", and "two or more races". The 2010 PL 94-171 data provides a value per Census Block for "one race" by race (PL 94-171 fields P0010003 through P0010008). / Persons of two or more races were calculated by subtracting "persons of one race" from "persons of 1 or more races".

Title: Race, Ethnicity, Housing Unit Calculations, 2010 Census Block Group Level, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 States
Description: The fields in this table are a combination of fields from the 2010 Public Law 94-171 table distributed by the US Census Bureau and calculations made by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS to support population "race/ethnicity" mapping by Census Block Group. The Census Block Group level calculations were made by summarizing the Census Block values per Census Block Group number. / Persons of two or more races were calculated by subtracting "persons of one race" from "persons of 1 or more races".

Title: New Mexico Oil Conservation Division Boundaries
Description: This dataset contains boundaries of New Mexico Oil Conservation Divisions as of May 2012. The dataset was created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Emergency Response GIS in support of Emergency Response mapping. 2010 TIGER/Line county boundary dataset was used to delineate the dataset.

Title: Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants as of 7/15/2012, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: This data layer contains boundaries of nonattainment areas in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 listed in the "Green Book of Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants" as of 7/15/2012. The layer was created using the Census Bureau TIGER/Line 2010 county layer and the list of Nonattainment areas designated as of 7/15/2012, available at http://www.epa.gov/air/oaqps/greenbk/index.html. The criteria pollutants involved in this data layer include 8-hour ozone, Lead (2008) and PM-10.

Title: Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants, 3/30/2012, Region 6
Description: This data layer contains boundaries of nonattainment areas listed in the "Green Book of Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants" as of 3/30/2012. The layer was created using the Census Bureau TIGER/Line 2010 county layer and the list of Nonattainment areas designated as of 3/30/2012, available at http://www.epa.gov/air/oaqps/greenbk/index.html. The criteria pollutants involved in this data layer include 8-hour ozone, Lead (2008) and PM-10.

Title: Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants as of 7/30/2013, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: This data layer contains boundaries of nonattainment areas in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 listed in the "Green Book of Nonattainment Areas for Criteria Pollutants" as of 7/30/2013. The layer was created using the Census Bureau TIGER/Line 2010 county layer and the list of Nonattainment areas designated as of 7/30/2013, available at http://www.epa.gov/air/oaqps/greenbk/index.html. Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 National Priorities List (NPL) Sites - 05/12/2014
Description: Point locations for sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 which are documented as being part of the National Priorities List as of May 12, 2014. The locations were determined by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Superfund RPMs.

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 National Priorities List (NPL) Boundaries - 05/12/2014
Description: Boundaries of sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 which are documented as being part of the National Priorities List as of May 12, 2014. The locations were determined by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Superfund RPMs.

Title: Sole Source Aquifers, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: Polygon layer of sole source aquifers in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6. The sole source aquifers represented are: Edwards I and Edwards II in Texas, Chicot and Southern Hills in Louisiana/Mississippi, Espanola in New Mexico, and Arbuckle-Simpson in Oklahoma. Edwards, Chicot, Southern Hills, and Arbuckle-Simpson boundaries published in 1996. Espanola boundaries added in January 2008.

Title: TRI (Toxic Release Inventory) Facilities 2011 in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: This dataset contains point location data extracted from the EPA Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) system for reporting year 2011 http://www.epa.gov/tri/. The dataset contains: facility identification, submitted and/or preferred location coordinates from TRI, Region 6 reviewed location coordinates (about 60% of the facilities), and release information.

Title: Railways in Mexico
Description: Dataset of railways in Mexico. Downloaded from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics and layers created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6.

Title: TEAP Rarity Layer (Raw Scores)
Description: The Texas Ecological Assessment Protocol (TEAP) is a screening level assessment tool created by a working group of the Texas Environmental Resource Stewards (TERS). The TEAP divides nineteen individual measures into three main layers: diversity, rarity, and sustainability. This feature class represents the rarity layer which shows the rarity of species and land cover in Texas. There are four measures that make up the rarity layer: vegetation rarity, natural heritage rank, taxonomic richness, and rare species richness. Each cell in the final diversity grid has a score of between 1 and 100 based on the average of the four measures. Cells with higher scores represent areas that have the most rarity. Cells with lower scores represent areas that have the least rarity. / TERS was established in July 2002 to seek greater Federal and State interagency collaboration on identifying and supporting joint priorities, particularly regarding transportation issues. Leaders from participating agencies (see Supplemental Information) jointly identified common interests and target activities for collaborative ecosystem management, thereby benefitting each agency. Common interests and uses included identification of highest priority natural resources areas (wetland, aquatic, terrestrial) for avoidance, mitigation, or potential compensation or restoration; "streamlining" of regulatory processes; early assistance with National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) planning; and analysis of cumulative impacts. TERS participants also identified uses for the TERS ecological assessment within each agency's mission. The vision, as developed by the TERS executives, included the following actions: Improve mutual understanding; Use collective knowledge to support decisions-making; and Strive for synergism. The TERS approach to achieving this vision was to use an ecosystem approach to organize strategies that achieve effective and measurable environmental results, and jointly communicate the results to the public. The initial goals of TERS were to identify high priority ecological areas, potential mitigation areas, and streamline the regulatory processes. The Texas Ecological Assessment Protocol (TEAP) is part of the first goal: the ecological assessment and identification of priority ecological resources in the state of Texas. Please refer to the 2005 report ( http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyPURL.cgi?Dockey=P100BLAF.txt ) for more details on TERS and the TEAP.

Title: RCRA Sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: This layer file contains the locations of RCRA sites in Region 6 as queried from the regional Facility Registry System (FRS) layer using the definition query "RCRA_ID" <> ''. The FRS layer was pulled on 3/25/2012 from a centrally managed database that identifies facilities, sites or places subject to environmental regulations or of environmental interest. The locations for some of the sites have been reviewed and updated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS.

Title: RCRA Sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6, 7/2011
Description: This dataset contains locations of RCRA TSD sites in Region 6 as of 7/23/2011 which were pulled from the regional FRS layer. The FRS layer was pulled from a centrally managed database that identifies facilities, sites or places subject to environmental regulations or of environmental interest. The locations for some of the sites have been reviewed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS.

Title: RCRA TSD Boundaries for U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6, 2009
Description: Database of RCRA Treatment, Storage, and Disposal facility boundaries developed by PRC Environmental Management, Inc (PRC), and the Region 6 GIS Support Team. Newly included in this database (as of 3/2009) are boundaries of Corrective Action sites that are also TSD's. / PRC performed per a Work Assignment from the U.S. EPA under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) Enforcement, Permitting, and Assistance (REPA) Contract No. 68-W4-0007. Under this contract, PRC verified and plotted the latitude and longitude of 596 RCRA facilities located in Region 6. QA/QC was performed by PRC and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS Support Team.

Title: RMP Sites in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: This data layer contains the locations of RMP sites in Region 6 as queried from the regional Facility Registry System (FRS) layer using the definition query "RMP" = 'Y'. The FRS layer was pulled on 3/25/2012 from a centrally managed database that identifies facilities, sites or places subject to environmental regulations or of environmental interest. The locations for some of the sites have been reviewed and updated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS.

Title: Sister Cities along US/Mexico Border
Description: Locations of 29 cities referred to as US and Mexico "Sister Cities." The locations of the cities were pulled from the Digital Chart of the World database, 1994. The EPA's OIA selected the city names that are included in this point layer.

Title: TEAP Sustainability Layer (Raw Scores)
Description: The Texas Ecological Assessment Protocol (TEAP) is a screening level assessment tool created by a working group of the Texas Environmental Resource Stewards (TERS). The TEAP divides nineteen individual measures into three main layers: diversity, rarity, and sustainability. This feature class represents the sustainability layer which describes the state of the environment in terms of stability (sustainble areas are those that can maintain themselves into the future without human management). There are eleven measures that make up the sustainability layer: contiguous land cover, regularity of ecosystem boundary, appropriateness of land cover, waterway obstruction, road density, airport noise, Superfund sites, Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) sites, water quality, air quality, and urban/agriculture disturbance. Each cell in the final sustainability grid has a score of between 1 and 100 based on the average of the eleven measures. Cells with higher scores represent areas that are more sustainable. Cells with lower scores represent areas that are the least sustainable. / TERS was established in July 2002 to seek greater Federal and State interagency collaboration on identifying and supporting joint priorities, particularly regarding transportation issues. Leaders from participating agencies (see Supplemental Information) jointly identified common interests and target activities for collaborative ecosystem management, thereby benefitting each agency. Common interests and uses included identification of highest priority natural resources areas (wetland, aquatic, terrestrial) for avoidance, mitigation, or potential compensation or restoration; "streamlining" of regulatory processes; early assistance with National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) planning; and analysis of cumulative impacts. TERS participants also identified uses for the TERS ecological assessment within each agency's mission. The vision, as developed by the TERS executives, included the following actions: Improve mutual understanding; Use collective knowledge to support decisions-making; and Strive for synergism. The TERS approach to achieving this vision was to use an ecosystem approach to organize strategies that achieve effective and measurable environmental results, and jointly communicate the results to the public. The initial goals of TERS were to identify high priority ecological areas, potential mitigation areas, and streamline the regulatory processes. The Texas Ecological Assessment Protocol (TEAP) is part of the first goal: the ecological assessment and identification of priority ecological resources in the state of Texas. Please refer to the 2005 report ( http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyPURL.cgi?Dockey=P100BLAF.txt) for more details on TERS and the TEAP.

Title: Tribal Headquarters for U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 Tribal Program recognizes 66 tribes/pueblos and 2 agencies. Locations for these areas are represented as points in this shapefile. All locations have been reviewed and placed at the tribal administration or tribal court building, when possible. Review the field "R6Accuracy" to determine if the confidence of the location's accuracy is (1) high level, (2) mid-to-high level, or (3) mid-level.

Title: R6 GISST 250m Grid
Description: Region 6 GIS Screening Tool / This file geodatabase layer contains grid cells for the extent of U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6, as clipped at shoreline and state boundaries. Each grid cell is 62,500 square meters (250m x 250m) in size and contains pre-calculated scores for various physical, environmental, and demographic data considered of importance to Region 6. / The project was initially started as a part of the NEPA streamlining effort for the I-69 Baseline Analysis Project in Texas. A grid of 1 square kilometer cells covering the entire State of Texas was created and various physical, environmental, and socio-economic factors were calculated. The factors could be used to identify issues of importance within the state and also to assist in identifying smaller study areas. After this initial work, the grid was recreated at a 62,500 square meter size. This version of the grid has now been extended to include all Region 6 states (Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Texas).

Title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 250 meter Grid Cells
Description: This file geodatabase layer contains 250 meter grid cells for the extent of U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6, as clipped at shoreline and state boundaries.

Title: 24k Quadrangle Boundaries in U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 States
Description: This layer includes boundaries of 1:24,000 quadrangles as created by U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6 GIS. Attributes for 1:100,000 quadrangles are included in the attribute table.

Title: ImageConnect Index for U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Region 6
Description: Index of imagery for Image Connect. No further documentation.
